discussion.content: EDIT: after further research the correct answer is C: Cable short for that particular cubical. A would occur with more employees around if that was the issue. The short is occuring in the plug that hooks the phone to the wall. The small cable box needs to be replaced.
I agree A is the correct answer because the situation occured when the person moved. If the cable was experiencing a short then it would have the same situation if it was replaced at the older area.
It seems A have to be correct answer

questions.question_text:
After moving to an adjacent cubicle, a user is reporting that the VoIP phone is randomly rebooting. When the technician relocates the equipment back to the previous space, the phone functions properly. No other stations are being affected.
Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?

The administrator would like to use the strongest encryption level possible using PSK without utilizing an additional authentication server.
Which of the following encryption types should be implemented?

discussion.content:
Interesting nugget to add with regards to WPA2-Enterprise (answer A):

'Sometimes you don’t even need the server: some access points come with built-in software that can operate 802.1X (though only for the smallest of small deployments).'

Ergo, if the network used to deploy the wireless authentication is small enough and the APs modern enough that are able to provide the authentication, then yes its technically possible to have WPA2-Enterprise without having to resort to using an external authentication server. But the problem remains that the admin want to use the PSK functionality which is only provided in WPA-personal and WPA2-personal, not enterprise. 

Either the question has been stated inaccurately, or the possible answers provided don't provide the correct solution to the question.

The administrator would like to use the strongest encryption level possible using PSK without utilizing an additional authentication server.
Which of the following encryption types should be implemented?

Answer 'A' is the correct answer either way as the other options in terms of security are at best laughable and basically only help to 'keep honest users honest'. 

But the scenario raised here by the question use strongest encryption level possible using PSK without utilizing an additional authentication server' raises altogether another question of using WPA2 Enterprise as a solution, which in most common deployments requires a RADIUS server - as in an authentication server. So, answer A is technically not the correct answer. 

If an Preshared Key functionality is needed without the use of an authentication server then WPA-Personal would be the only (not recommended though) answer.

More can be read here:

The differences between WPA-Personal and WPA-Enterprise
https://www.tp-link.com/uk/support/faq/500/?utm_medium=select-local

Another good article on the topic (highly recommended):

Simplifying WPA2-Enterprise and 802.1X
https://www.securew2.com/solutions/wpa2-enterprise-and-802-1x-simplified/

questions.question_text:
The human resource department has been moved to an area which is more than 60 meters away from the nearest IDF.
In order to comply with the SLA which requires that 10Gb speeds be provided, which of the following media will need to utilized?

discussion.content:
'CAT6e is not an actual standard. It has not been implemented or qualified by the TIA or any other reputable organization or commission. CAT6e is incomparable to CAT6 because the standard technically does not exist. A correct comparison would be between CAT6 and CAT6A. CAT6 is the original version, while CAT6A is the advanced version.'

Although CAT6e is not technically a recognized standard, some manufacturers still manufacture products labeled with the CAT6e classification. For their purposes, CAT6e means CAT6 “enhanced”. It indicates enhancements of the original CAT6 specification that exceed the TIA limit. Typically, CAT6e claims to: double transmission frequency from 250MHz to 500MHz or even 550MHz; be equipped with a grounded foil shielding that helps data transmission reach up to 10 Gigabit Ethernet; and extend to a maximum length of 100 meters.

Good for further reading...

What are the differences between CAT6, CAT6e, and CAT6A?
https://www.cablesys.com/updates/cat6-cat6e-cat6a-differences/

comments.content: I think port 21 because the server is remotely connected
I agree with you; its SFTP which is Port 22

discussion.content:
Why port 21 when the question clearly states a requirement for a secure connection? any network engineer worth his/her salt knows that FTP (ports 20 /21) is not secure!

Won't bother to further this line of discussion other than sharing the following link and say (hint) STFP protocol uses the port that is the correct answer.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_TCP_and_UDP_port_numbers

discussion.content: Opinion rather than a concrete answer.

questions.question_text:
A technician is called to investigate a connectivity issue to a remote office that is connected by fiber optic cable. Using a light meter, it is determined that the Db loss is excessive. The installation has been working for several years. The switch was recently moved to the other side of the room and a new patch cord installed.
Which of the following is MOST likely the cause of the issue?
